title: Boris Johnson: Stories about my conduct are designed to stop Brexit
text:
Boris Johnson at the annual Conservative Party conference | Ben Stansall/AFP via Getty Images Boris Johnson: Stories about my conduct are designed to stop Brexit The prime minister said the claims could also be an attempt to distract from his domestic agenda.

MANCHESTER, England — Boris Johnson suggested Tuesday allegations about his personal conduct are part of a political plot to stop Brexit.

The prime minister said a claim by journalist Charlotte Edwardes that he grabbed her thigh at a lunch in the late 1990s was “shot and shell” against his plans to take Britain out of the EU on October 31.

Johnson has also faced allegations he funneled public cash grants to the business of a friend, Jennifer Arcuri, and allowed her to accompany him on trade trips her firm was not eligible for while he was mayor of London.

Asked on LBC Radio at the Conservative Party conference in Manchester why the stories had arisen, Johnson said there was “a very good reason.”

“And that is that I’ve been tasked one way or the other to get Brexit done by October 31,” he explained. “And there are quite a lot of well-meaning and highly-intelligent people who basically think that will be something they don’t want to see. And I think that there is a concerted effort now to frustrate Brexit.”

"I think that there is a concerted effort now to frustrate Brexit" — Boris Johnson

Asked if he was putting the Edwardes claim down to political motivation, he said: “I don’t want to impugn people’s motives or to minimize the importance of the issue. All I can say is that that allegation is certainly not true."

Edwardes, who made the allegation in a column in the Sunday Times, tweeted later Sunday that she stood by her story after the prime minister's spokesperson said it was untrue. "If the prime minister doesn’t recollect the incident then clearly I have a better memory than he does," she tweeted.
description: The prime minister said the claims could also be an attempt to distract from his domestic agenda.
